title: 1)	Design Optimization of Cooling Channels in Friction Stir Channeled Liquid Cold Plates through Heat Transfer Simulation
description:
The increasing thermal loads in modern electronic devices and battery systems demand efficient and compact cooling solutions to avoid overheating and increase the performance & lifecycle of the systems. Liquid Cold plates have emerged as a promising technology for thermal management of these devices. In view of this, Friction Stir Channeling (FSC), a friction stir welding derived technique, manufactures a leak proof integrated channel with higher thermal cooling efficiency, compared to conventional techniques such as liquid brazing.
The project focuses on the optimization of the integrated channel path and geometry manufactured through FSC using a developed heat transfer model. The modelling work will be performed in COMSOL Multiphysics. The primary objective is to achieve the desired heat transfer efficiency by studying temperature distribution, pressure drop, and overall thermal resistance. Based on the simulation results, the design of the internal channel such as channel path and geometry will be optimized to achieve the required thermal performance as specified by the industry.

title: 2)	Optimization of the Model Parameters for the Heat Transfer and Material Flow model for Additive Friction Stir Deposition of Copper
description: Additive Friction Stir Deposition (AFSD) is an advanced solid-state additive manufacturing technique based on the principles of friction stir welding. A rotating hollow non-consumable tool is used to generate the heat through the friction and plastic deformation. A feed stock in the form of rod is supplied through the hollow tool portion which plasticizes due to the frictional heat generated between the tool-substrate interface and gets deposited on the substrate. The Finite volume method-based heat transfer and material flow model framework for the AFSD is developed. The project aims to optimize the model parameters and analyse their effects on the output for the AFSD of copper. The predicted results will be visualized using dedicated plotting software for further analysis. The predicted thermal cycle from the model will be validated using experimental thermal cycle data from existing literature.

title: A Priori Assessment of LES–PCA Modeling for Hydrogen-Enriched Jet-in-Crossflow Flames Using DNS Data
description: This project conducts an a priori assessment of a Principal Component Analysis (PCA)-based reduced-order modeling framework for hydrogen-enriched jet-in-crossflow flames using existing DNS datasets. The study focuses on extracting dominant thermo-chemical features, applying LES filtering to emulate coarse-resolution simulations, and evaluating how accurately a truncated PCA representation reconstructs key combustion quantities such as temperature, species mass fractions, and heat release rate. Through this work, the student will gain hands-on experience in handling large scientific datasets, applying dimensionality reduction techniques to complex physical systems, understanding turbulence–combustion interactions and LES scale separation, and developing reproducible scientific workflows.

title: Accelerating Combustion CFD Using Neural ODEs Based Chemical Kinetics Models
description: This project involves coupling a Neural ODEs Based chemical kinetics model with a combustion CFD solver (OpenFOAM). In conventional combustion CFD, chemical source terms are computed using detailed reaction mechanisms, which makes simulations computationally expensive. The intern will replace the detailed chemistry calculations with the data driven model and ensure the coupled solver remains stable, accurate, and physically consistent. The implementation will be tested on benchmark cases such as a 1D/2D deflageration laminar flames, and results will be validated by comparing laminar flame speed, temperature profiles, and major species distributions against a detailed chemistry.

title: AI Accelerator design for RISC-V based MCU
description:
We are currently in the process of designing a RISC-V clone of the Atmega328p microcontroller and testing it against an FPGA board.

This project will involve adding an ML accelerator unit to the microcontroller that will allow for faster and low power edge inference.

title: AI-Driven Diffusion Modeling for Flow-Field Reconstruction in Couette Systems
description: The work focuses on Couette flow configurations spanning a large and complex parameter space, supported by an extensive database generated from high-fidelity CFD simulations. to develop and deploy diffusion-based generative models for efficient reconstruction and representation of flow-field data. By enabling accurate recovery of complex flow structures across varying operating conditions, this study seeks to establish diffusion models as transformative tools for fluid dynamics research, with applications ranging from super-resolution and reduced-order modeling to  data reconstruction and data-driven discovery. Once model is developed, this can be extended to experimental data too.

title: Algorithms for Group Theoretic Problems
description:
Group theory has played a central role in understanding the complexity of various problems, such as the graph isomorphism problem and problems arising in number theory. In quantum computation, a majority of the problems for which quantum computers have been shown to exhibit exponential speed-ups over classical algorithms are, in fact, group-theoretic problems.

In this project, we plan to study the complexity of group-theoretic problems related to group representations. More specifically, we aim to design efficient algorithms for computing representations of certain classes of permutation groups.

title: Analysing economic relationships using large scale household surveys
description: The project will require working with large datasets, such as IHDS or NFHS or other similar surveys, to analyse economic relationships. The candidate must be well-versed with econometric techniques, and with statistical software tools like Stata or R. Candidates may also be required to carry out literature reviews on topics related to development economics. Candidates may be asked to go on field, if required, for necessary data collection. Application of candidates with strong econometric analysis and data processing skills will be favoured and considered for further processing. Candidate must share examples of their related skills while applying.

title: Asymmetric Organocatalysis
Automated Gait and Posture Analysis
description: In this one is expected to work with various sensors to quantify and analyze one's gait and posture

title: Battery data analytics platform
description: This project involves the creation of an end to end platform for collecting, storing and visualizing data from smart batteries, including changing the designs of existing battery management system hardware, if required. The health, sensor data and other information from the battery management system is then sent to a scalable and secure SaaS platform that allows high speed ingestion and management of battery data (anything that a BMS can provide) from a large fleet of IoT batteries, from multiple providers and exposes relevant analytics, management and alerting capabilities to multiple stakeholders in the ecosystem including battery manufacturers and OEMs.

title: Battery Management System
description: In this project the interns will build a BMS hardware for a bicycle battery pack from scratch and learn implement EV safety control algorithim under varying drive cycles and ambient conditions.

title: Brain Computer Interface
description: Project involves analysis of Brain data from EEG and fNIRS with classical and machine learning approaches

title: Building Capacity in Sustainable Development: Designing and Implementing Professional Certificate Programmes
description:
Professional certificate programmes play an important role in building capacity to address emerging sustainability and environmental challenges. This internship will support the development and implementation of certificate courses in areas such as Circular Economy and ESG, Water Governance and Management, and Pollution Prevention and Environmental Compliance.

The intern will review existing national and international certificate and executive programmes, identify key themes and learning objectives, and contribute to designing a structured course outline, including modules, learning outcomes, and delivery formats. The intern will also help identify potential resource persons, target participants, and programme timelines.

In addition, the intern may support preparation of course materials, outreach, coordination with experts, and execution of the certificate programme.

This internship is suitable for students interested in sustainability, environmental management, water resources, pollution control, public policy, or related fields. The internship will provide exposure to curriculum development, sustainability frameworks, and implementation of professional training programmes.

title: Buried Channel Array Transistors (BCAT) for advanced DRAM Node
description: BCATs are critical to modern DRAM technologies for mitigating short-channel effects (SCE) and improving off-current performance. The objective of this project is to simulate and optimize BCAT device structures to achieve higher on-current and lower off-current, enabling improved DRAM performance and scalability. A strong foundation in semiconductor device physics and hands-on experience with TCAD simulation tools are required for this project.

title: CFD Analysis of Differentially Rotating Spherical Couette Flows
description: Spherical Couette flow, defined as the flow between two concentric spheres with independently rotating inner and outer boundaries. The rotation of both spheres introduces complex shear-driven dynamics, leading to a rich spectrum of flow regimes ranging from laminar axisymmetric states to non-axisymmetric instabilities and turbulence. The simulations solve the incompressible Navier–Stokes equations in spherical geometry, enabling systematic exploration of the effects of Reynolds number and rotation ratios on flow transitions and structure formation. The project is bases developing numerical code based on open source Dedalus. This work also involve mathematical formulation in spherical coordinated and coordinate transformation.

title: CFD modelling of noise barriers
description: Urban expansion and increasing traffic density have led to heightened noise pollution, which significantly impacts public health and quality of life. While physical noise barriers are standard mitigation tools, their effectiveness is often compromised by complex atmospheric conditions, varied barrier geometries, and the diffraction of sound waves over the barrier top. Traditional empirical models often fail to account for the intricate interaction between wind turbulence and sound propagation. There is a critical need to develop a high-fidelity computational framework to accurately predict the Insertion Loss (IL)—the reduction in sound pressure level—provided by different barrier designs. This project aims to develop such a framework using the open-source CFD solver, OpenFOAM. Prior knowledge of OpenFOAM is preferred but not necessary. Knowledge of ParaView is useful. Students from Civil or Mechanical/Aerospace Engineering are preferred.

title: Chemical crystallography of small molecules
description: Structure determination and intermolecular interaction studies of small molecules via single crystal XRD.

title: ChitraBasha: Building Indic Vision-language Dataset
Chloroplast genome assembly of medicinal plants
description:
This summer internship project focuses on the de novo assembly and annotation of chloroplast genomes from selected medicinal plants, using high-throughput sequencing data. Students will process raw Illumina or Nanopore reads through quality control (FastQC, Trimmomatic), perform chloroplast genome assembly with tools like NOVOPlasty or GetOrganelle, and annotate genes (rRNAs, tRNAs, protein-coding regions) via CpGAVAS2 or GeSeq, followed by comparative analyses to identify variations in inverted repeat regions, simple sequence repeats, and phylogenetically informative markers. The project aims to generate reference cp-genomes for biodiversity assessment, authentication of herbal drugs, and evolutionary studies, contributing to conservation genomics of India's medicinal flora.
Desired skill sets
.Basic bioinformatics proficiency 
.Familiarity with NGS data analysis tools (e.g., FastQC, SPAdes, BLAST).
.Good Molecular biology knowledge (plant genetics, organelle genomes).
.Data visualization skills (e.g., Circos for genome maps, IQ-TREE for phylogenetics).
.Willingness to learn assembly pipelines and submit to NCBI GenBank.

title: Comparison theorems in ordinary differential equations
description: This project deals with the qualitative questions in ordinary differential equations (ODEs). In this context, Sturm's comparison theorem plays an important role. We study comprehensively the Sturm's comparison theorem, and intend to prove a generalization of it to a pair of nonlinear ODEs.

title: Computational Biomaterials
description: The student will use computational tools to understand biomaterial physics

title: Computational investigation of circadian clock proteins
description: The project involves computational investigation of clock proteins including virtual screening and simulations.

title: Creating Digital Photo Archive using an Open-Source software & Curating and Organising Virtual and Physical Exhibition of Archival Materials
description:
Over a period of last 18 years, the different units of the Institute have accumulated good number of photographs of Institute’s important events, activities, individuals, groups etc.  As these serve as memory of the Institute, some of these photographs need to be archived in a systematic manner for future use. This proposed project will involve the work of identifying, evaluating, and selecting a suitable software for creating a digital archive (prototype) of such. This would also require installing and customizing the software, populating with photographs, and providing access to the same.
The second and most important part of the project is, what it takes (covering all aspects) to plan, design and organise a theme based virtual and physical exhibition of all types of archival materials. Selected intern is expected to have the knowledge of the archival materials ( print and digital) and some amount of demonstrated skills and experience of curating and organising a professional exhibition for the archives and museums.

title: Creating district linking data for governance and district data mapping tool
description: India governance data is fragmented and stored within states. States over the years redistribute district administration boundaries and with that it also changes the revenue data collection and monitoring. For economists trying to understand the resource management and development indicators across districts, the changed district boundaries and data collection proves to be a challenge for panel data analysis. In this project we attempt to create apportionment of data and linking with the previous district boundaries to map the development, agriculture, and socio-demographic datasets with consistent time series. The time series matching tool developed through the project shall help the state and national government with the digital India initiative and better governance planning and resource allocation.

title: Crypto-Acceleration: Designing Hardware Accelerator for Post Quantum Cryptography
description: In this project various lattice based PQC algorithms will be implemented on different hardware platforms including FPGAs. This project requires the students to explore all the existing Lattice based cryptography algorithms and accelerate the most time consuming operations. The work also will explore modeling PQC on hardware accelerator platforms.

title: Data driven dynamical modeling of chiral structure
description: ​Chiral uni-cells have translation generalized coordinates in addition to rotational degree of freedom. The tangentially connected extensible Kirchhoff rod contributes to the elastic energy of the system. However, an analytical closed form governing equation is seldom realizable since one has to solve the configuration of the rod to obtain the elastic energy at every instant. To this end, we consider numerically generated data to approximate a generalized governing equation applicable over varying energies and possibly correlate with the geometric properties of the ligaments

title: Deep Image Restoration
description: Design and develop modern deep networks for achieving image restoration tasks such as denoising, deblurring, inpainting, and super-resolution. Application domains include space and biomedical.

title: Design and development of a large scale electronic-cooling system
description: The large scale electronics in various applications generate a lot of heat and require continuous cooling. A liquid coolant based large scale cooling system is to be designed for such system. The work will involve basic CAD designing, FEM/FVM simulations, and hands-on designing of systems.

title: Design and development of Stress Concentration Factors for Joints in structural members
description: SCF is an important estimate, governing the strenght  of different types of joints in maritime steel structures. API codes give emprical equations for various types of joints. This project aims to develop a complete coding in Matlab (at the back end) and any other app such as Visual Basic or Python in the front end. The developed app should help enigneers to estimate the SCF and design teh joints, which  they otherwise do through expensive software.

title: Design and prototyping of Electromagnetic Vibration Energy Harvester
description: Goal is to develop a miniaturized micropower electromagnetic vibration energy harvester for self-powered battery-less sensors. First step is design validation by simulation over COMSOL Multiphysics, followed by hardware prototyping, and experimental testing. Familiarity with COMSOL or other FEM tool is required. Past experience with hardware prototyping is preferred.

title: Design and Realization of a Dual-Channel GaN HEMT Based on a Three-Layer Heterostructure for Depletion-Mode Applications
description:
This project investigates a depletion-mode (normally-on) dual-channel GaN High Electron Mobility Transistor (HEMT) based on a three-layer heterostructure architecture for high- power electronic applications. The proposed structure incorporates two vertically separated two-dimensional electron gas (2DEG) channels formed at engineered
heterointerfaces, enabling enhanced carrier transport, reduced access resistance, and improved electric-field distribution. The dual-channel configuration facilitates effective current sharing and improved electrostatic control, resulting in higher drain current capability, increased transconductance, and reduced hot-electron effects while
maintaining stable D-mode operation. The three-layer heterostructure provides strong carrier confinement and minimizes interaction with buffer-related traps, thereby suppressing current collapse and dynamic on-resistance degradation under high-voltage operation. The study integrates TCAD-based modeling with DC and pulsed I–V characterization to optimize device performance, offering a scalable pathway toward reliable GaN-based power electronic devices.

title: Design and Realization of a E/D-Mode GaN Active-Passivation HEMT (ED-APHEMT) for Power applications
description:
Conventional depletion-mode GaN HEMTs offer high current density and low on-resistance but require negative gate bias for safe operation, whereas enhancement-mode devices enable fail-safe normally-off operation at the cost of reduced current capability and
increased dynamic degradation. Motivated by the need to combine safe gate control with high-performance conduction in a single device platform, this project proposes a novel Enhancement/Depletion-mode (E/D-mode) GaN Active-Passivation High Electron Mobility Transistor (APHEMT) based on engineered heterostructure and gate–passivation
co-design. The device concept integrates an active passivation layer that electrically interacts with the channel to modulate surface potential and electric-field distribution, enabling controlled E/D-mode operation within a single device architecture. The proposed approach reduces surface trap effects, suppresses current collapse, and improves
dynamic on-resistance under high-voltage operation. The active passivation layer plays a critical role in mitigating surface-related trapping and enhancing electrostatic control in the gate–drain access region. The study combines TCAD-based electrostatic and transport
modeling with DC and pulsed I–V characterization to optimize device performance. The proposed E/D-mode GaN Active-Passivation HEMT offers a scalable pathway toward reliable, high-efficiency GaN power electronic devices.

title: Design of Custom Graphical Elements for Assistive Interfaces
description:
Overview & Expected Contribution
This project involves designing custom graphical elements/fonts for assistive and multimodal interface systems. The goal is to create clear, accessible, and visually consistent visual components that can be integrated into research prototypes and interactive applications. The intern will create scalable vector-based graphical elements and UI assets using illustration tools. By the end of the project, the intern should deliver a well-structured set of graphical assets ready for integration into digital systems.
Required Skills
The intern should have basic experience with vector illustration tools such as FontForge, Inkscape, Adobe Illustrator, or similar software. A general understanding of graphic design principles is expected.
Preferred Skills
Prior experience in UI/UX design, accessibility-focused design, or creating scalable vector graphics will be beneficial, but is not mandatory. A portfolio of previous design work will be appreciated.

title: Developing AI models for Nanofiltration membrane design
description: Nanofiltration membranes are attractive for numerous applications due to its low energy operation. However, fabricating controlled pore structures in such membranes have been challenging. The intern will use AI models to find the optimum fabrication procedure for such membranes.

title: Developing Hands-on Learning Modules on Physics using a Smartphone for Science Education
description: This project aims to turn smartphone into a scientific tool to study physics. The internship will explore how internal sensors such as accelerometers, gyroscope, barometer, and light meters can be used to conduct physics experiments outside of a traditional lab setting. While the phone acts as the primary data logger, you have to build some creative physical setups, to expand the scope of the measurements. The intern will focus on reading and understanding articles, execute experiments using smartphone, and document them.

title: Development of a Bio-Inspired Electronic Skin for Robotic Tactile Sensing and Adaptive Interaction
description:
This project proposes an exploratory research investigation and prototype development of a bio-inspired artificial skin system aimed at enhancing robotic perception, compliance, and physical interaction capabilities. As robots increasingly operate within human-centric environments, the development of tactilely responsive interfaces is critical for enabling safe manipulation, adaptive behaviour, and context-aware interaction.
The internship will begin with a structured scientific review of the morphological, mechanical, and sensory characteristics of human skin, with particular emphasis on its multilayer architecture, viscoelastic behaviour, and distributed sensing mechanisms. Interns will examine contemporary advances in artificial skin (e-skin), soft material systems, flexible electronics, and robotic tactile sensing, with the objective of identifying technological gaps, performance limitations, and unresolved research challenges.
Building upon this analytical foundation, interns will formulate an engineering-driven design framework for a multilayer artificial skin architecture that functionally approximates key characteristics of biological tissue, including compliance, resilience, and pressure sensitivity. The project will involve the experimental exploration of soft polymers, elastomers, and bio-derived materials to evaluate their suitability for layered fabrication and sensor embedding.
Subsequently, interns will design and fabricate an initial proof-of-concept artificial skin prototype incorporating tactile sensing elements and a basic data acquisition interface. Emphasis will be placed on material compatibility, structural stability, signal fidelity, and repeatable fabrication workflows suitable for robotic deployment.
The developed artificial skin will undergo preliminary mechanical characterization to assess parameters such as flexibility, deformation response, and durability. In parallel, sensing performance will be evaluated through controlled touch-based experiments to examine sensitivity, response consistency, and noise behaviour.
For system-level validation, the artificial skin will be mechanically and electronically integrated with a physical robotic substructure such as a robotic finger, gripper, or hand to enable foundational interaction experiments. These demonstrations will help assess the feasibility of the proposed architecture in real-world robotic manipulation contexts, particularly where compliant contact and tactile awareness are essential.

title: Development of a digital image correlation system
description: This project is to develop and validate a low-cost digital image correlation system. The purpose of the set-up will be to measure the deformations and strains in a structural component made of steel, concrete or other material.

title: Development of Advanced Process Control (APC) for semiconductor process tool parts-MFC and process heater
description: This project involves connecting and controlling semiconductor tool parts by APC. This process is widely used in semiconductor fab for process control. This project will involve the electrical connection, data acquisition, and analysis of the real-time data for process optimization using LabVIEW and MATLAB.

description:
Translate an existing Python-based plasma simulation code into C++, integrate it with an existing C++ PMC framework and develop a desktop GUI for user-friendly simulation control and visualisation. The final outcome will be a standalone executable for scientific and engineering applications.
Pre requisites: Strong proficiency in C++, CUDA and Python, experience with numerical methods and scientific computing, familiarity with ODE solvers and Monte Carlo methods, and basic knowledge of GUI frameworks (preferably Qt) and CMake-based build systems.

title: Development of food-to-food enriched nutritional products for deployment in mid-day meal scheme for school children
description: In this project the intern will be trained in nutritional food product development in the specific domain of food-to-food enrichment using food products that are regionally and culturally relevant. The work will involve learning methods for nutritional profiling and analysis, assessment of cellular response to nutrients present in the developed food products, and food sensory evaluation.

title: Development of Hands-on Learning Modules on Plant Biology for Science Education
description: This project aims to develop hands-on learning modules in Biology education for high schools in India. The internship will explore topics in plant physiology, cell biology, and bio-art through seed germination & tropism studies, respiration experiments, plant tissue microscopy, vegetative propagation, chromatography-based pigment analysis, bioplastic products and epoxy resin jewellery. The intern will focus on experimental design, standardisation of protocols, data recording, and scientific documentation."

Development of machine learning force fields for metallic alloys
